Morn, sweetly blushing, leaves her dewy bed,</br>Air's thousand tongues her welcome advent tell;</br>But, hark, from yonder mansion of the dead</br>Why tolls so dismally the village bell?
It was not wont thus to appal my ear,</br>As, with the dawn, I oft have hailed its chime,</br>Or oft, at eventide, have linger'd near,</br>To count each stroke, that mark'd the flight of time.

But now, through wood and glen, with heavy sound,</br>Its long dull echoes load the morning breeze,</br>That seems in sighs to ask the hills around,</br>"When heard ye e'er such sickening notes as these?"
For none before this peaceful vale had known,</br>Save such as speak of fleeting hours the while</br>Or such as summon, with their solemn tone,</br>The neighb'ring hamlet to yon sacred pile
Or, haply, save some more impressive chime,</br>That greets the parted spirit to its home;</br>But ne'er before, through long remember'd time,</br>Such sound as this had left yon village dome.
But, hark again!  it is the convict's knell,</br>The warning voice of death — and lo!  'tis past;</br>Now, child of sorrow, quit thy prison-cell,</br>Thy cup of bitterness to drain at last.
A few short moments make thy life a dream,</br>Which the oblivious dawn hath chased away;</br>Yet, as the vision flies, perchance a gleam</br>Shall turn the coming prospect into day.
Nor let fastidious virtue here deny</br>Some little solace to so drear a doom,</br>Nor think, the beam, that lives beyond the sky,</br>Ne'er cheers the passage to the convict's tomb.

Some there may be, whose deeds, of blackest hue,</br>Cloud with reflective gloom their parting hour;</br>Yet even these, in their dark fate, may view</br>Some ray, that glimmers from hope's beacon-tow'r.
Though their career was mark'd with many a stain,</br>Though infamy hath closed their transient day,</br>Yet, who shall say, repentance wept in vain,</br>To wash their errors or their crimes away?
And few are they, to guilt howe'er allied,</br>That die the sullen martyrs of despair,</br>Nor seek, ere life hath spent its ebbing tide,</br>What balm may flow from penitence and prayer.
If, then, for these meek charity may plead,</br>Their fate remember'd, but their lives forgiven,</br>Say, shall they ask in vain the pious meed,</br>Whom dark affliction led astray from heaven?
And such was he, whom now yon awful chime</br>Hath summon'd to his ignominious tomb:</br>He once was happy — once was free from crime,</br>And hope still pointed to a fairer doom:

Yes, he had known, ere came time's chilling blight,</br>To crop the promise of his vernal hour,</br>Each buoyant thought, still teeming with delight,</br>That loves to hover near life's opening flower.
But, what avails it, that the muse's page</br>Records, that once it was his lot to roam,</br>Where heaven had giv'n him a paternal sage</br>And all the early treasures of a home?
Yes, what avails it all?  for him in vain</br>The muse may now a father's worth recal;</br>For, whether mingled with the sportive train,</br>Or at his task, a father guided all.
Yet now of pastime pure, or moral lore,</br>What vestige lives to tell his happier day?</br>Vain all the light instruction gave, no more</br>It sheds for him one kind consoling ray.

Then deem not those unbless'd, whose humbler wing</br>Was ne'er for science's proud flight design'd:</br>If not to these heaven opens wisdom's spring,</br>She keeps the coarser torrents from their mind.
Had he, who now invites my mournful song,</br>In ignorance's vale obscurely stray'd,</br>No lure, mayhap, had tempted him to wrong,</br>Nor misery found him in his lowly shade:
Perchance he still had walked as Nature led,</br>Nor turn'd aside to error's darkling way,</br>True to the path, where noiseless virtues tread,</br>And meek Contentment hymns her evening lay.
But him, alas!  his wayward fate had thrown</br>On the wide ocean of the boist'rous world;</br>Then fled each tranquil scene the past had known,</br>As life's rough bark her sweeping sail unfurl'd.
Too long he dared the treacherous gale to brave,</br>Nor deem'd misfortune's lowering tempest near;</br>But, ah!  it came, and, with its whelming wave,</br>The wreck of all to fame and honour dear.
Then learn to prize their calmer joys, who lead,</br>From such wild tumult free, their humble life,</br>By cares unvex'd, as waves the slender reed</br>In peace beneath the angry whirlwind's strife.
Yet here let Candour pause, nor blush to ask,</br>If aught may palliate his ignoble doom:</br>For heaven and charity have taught the task,</br>To drop the tear of pity on the tomb.
And let it fall; for here no love of crime,</br>That robs our nature of its brighter part,</br>Had torn away each attribute sublime,</br>To wreathe its toils around the victim's heart.
No thirst of blood, no savage lust of gain,</br>Had there impell'd the culprit to his fate;</br>For then Compassion had not wept in pain,</br>Nor Mercy sighed to close her golden gate.
But lo!  Affliction here had mark'd her prey,</br>Here sunk a wretch beneath her deadly blow;</br>Yet long he pined (for long is Misery's day)</br>A friendless wanderer in this vale of woe.
And much he bore ere virtue's generous flame,</br>By sorrow quench'd, no longer glowed to save,</br>Ere Nature's struggling pangs reposed in shame,</br>And one sad deed prepared his early grave.
Yet not unwept he falls, nor think the tear,</br>That dews his urn, to causeless anguish given;</br>It is a drop to sweet affection dear,</br>A drop to prove, her tenderest ties are riven.
But, haply, thus some bard, in after time,</br>As pensive wanderings lead him to the spot,</br>Shall o'er his tomb preserve, in hasty rhyme,</br>The plain, but hapless record of his lot.
"Here rests a youth, who lived the child of woe,</br>Whose death was stamp'd with ignominy's stain;</br>Yet he had known each fairer gift below,</br>But science smil'd, and virtue warm'd, in vain.

"Still, who shall say (to man 'twas never given),</br>That endless vengeance waits on rash offence?</br>Grant he hath err'd, but who shall say, that heaven</br>Shall ne'er to him her saving power dispense?
"Though some there be, whose firmly pious path</br>One even  tenour holds from youth to age,</br>No crossing fear have they of coming wrath,</br>As busy conscience turns o'er memory's page:
"Clear is their hope as evening's cloudless sun,</br>And, as it lights them hence, it sends a ray,</br>Whose gleam still lingers, though their course be run,</br>In golden earnest of a brighter day.
"Yet, pilgrim, stay — nor pass disdainful by,</br>Heedless of him, whose ashes here repose;</br>Nor deem in fault the heart, that yields a sigh</br>In secret pity to the convict's woes.

"For learn, he once had known (as thou may'st know)</br>Each nameless transport dearest kindred share,</br>Each home-born bliss, that gilds our fate below,</br>Or spreads a smile across the brow of care.

"But want o'erwhelming came:  his all to save,</br>He sinn'd, he fell — and so may fall the best;</br>For wife and child beloved he fills this grave—</br>Now, stranger, pass, and leave to heaven the rest."</br>
